According to Natalia it is usually good to castle because your king is generally under attack.  However there are occasions where you should not castle because your king is not attacked. The hallmark move of the Sozin system.
Other moves have been tried here 6. ...e5 for example with mixed results. The text is the steadiest forcing White's cleric to "bite on granite."

This is the diagnostic move of the Richter-Rauzer variation which is quite unlike the Sozin in its strategic aims. The Sozin is a positional system that puts steady pressure primarily on Black's center and White typically castles toward his KR. In the Richter-Rauzer White initiates an often bluntly tactical K-side attack usually featuring a raging pawnstorm and so he almost always castles long the better to facilitate it. Mixing the systems can be done but because their goals are dissimilar pursuing both strategies at once can easily lead to a confused game for White.

A fashion that comes and goes. This thrust used to be played commonly then fell out of favor after White started sacking on b5 often getting lasting positional pressure for the piece plus all those joined unopposed Q-side pawns staring Black into the endgame. The move has lately come back into fashion as defensive resources have improved and the complications no longer favor White as much as they once did. Still Black walks on brittle ice and must play the defense very precisely if White accepts the challenge to sac a piece as he does here.

This move holds d6 and with it the center but compels Black to play the rest of his game with shattered pawns on both wings. White gets good activity for the piece he's about to invest but not quite the attack he was undoubtedly playing for.
Black must react energetically but dares not exchange too many pieces - and definitely not his Queen! - or White's Q-side phalanx will spring to life.
The check doesn't matter; it was White's Knight that was dangerous. Now White no longer has a quick way to put pressure on d6.
Black's position is as ugly as a hillbilly family reunion but it's hard to crack ...and he's a piece ahead.

White gives Black a free tempo. Coming from a solid A-player the text is simply incomprehensibly weak an almost completely wasted move.

White is committing the cardinal sin of chess - moving without a coherent plan. The text obviously supports a push to d4 (even after a preliminary attempt at a break at b4) ...which lets the e-pawn hang. Or perhaps White wants to stop Black's Knight from hopping to d4 ...where it could then easily be chased by the c-pawn or exchanged from f3. I don't know what White was thinking to engage in this pointless dithering.

Notice that it's now taken White 3 moves to fully set up a pawn-push he had the option of playing on the 2nd or 3rd move of the game. Meanwhile Black has already gained a lead in development merely by playing naturally.

White bottles up his Queen a natural supporting piece to the push to d4 behind the QN which had no other square to develop to and in the process also blocks his QB; so Black moves to make the push to d4 even less appealing. The right move was 9. Be3 continuing to put pressure on the square.

Black "dithers" more effectively than White whose push to h3 accomplishes exactly nothing addresses exactly no threat. It was said by Fischer of Petrosian that the great Russian defensive genius had a gift for making innocuous-looking pawn moves in the opening that turned out to have great prophylactic significance 15 or 20 moves later in the middle game. That's not the case here. Black's "dithering" at least threatens ...b5 gaining space and a tempo.

Ah White's plan becomes clear - to push a pawn to f4 to gain influence in the center. And to achieve just the threat to accomplish this all White had to do was remove from the center a Knight that was already there influencing it. ...The word "anti-positional" comes to mind.
